Benjamin Schwyn I started out near the moral outrage camp (more like bullying defense rather than caring about any abstract moral principles), and moved to "I would play some similar game as slug bug". Basically, I don't like that that to play slug bug requires me to pay attention to boring things like cars. But if you hit me when you saw a car, and I hit you with some other agreed upon thing, that would work.

i got to the part soon after hormesis and though that had I skipped the entire article and just read the conclusion about the chilling effect I would have reached the same conclusion. Well, maybe if you had written any other random stuff in between to establish reader trust.

I didn't really understand the connection to the social ownership of micro, though it was interesting--- or I can see it in the paragraph starting with "and yes, the ideal that the anti-punch-bug crowd is striving for....", but that didn't feel quite relevant to the reason I was against punch bug. I was against punch bug because it felt like personal violation, rather than a moral one. However in general I don't find myself convinced by moral arguments.

What did convince me was 1) recognition that I had enough emotional resilience to let things pass, and 2) recognition that I can come up with my own form of play to get them back, 3) excuses for touch seem good for me..

What I was expecting for a conclusion was that we should play social-verbal punch-bag micro, where you share internal locus-of-control style micro observations that are both positive and negative, and develop some resistance to these sorts of things.

I have some friends I worked with everyday for a year who I would describe as more bro-ish, and one thing I discovered was that they had a social norm of constantly teasing each other which after trust was established morphed to just constantly pointing out micro social information of all types. I could write a lot about this, but instead I'll just write a bunch of words (emotional management, testing the resilience of your allies, finding the boundaries and weaknesses of your allies, constant doom circles + glory circles, roughhousing). It sounds similar to social punch bug and was a very good experience. But the trust was there before the teasing and the micro, and part of what made it a good experience was that they were extremely attentive to how much pushing they were doing.

Brent Dill > was a very good experience. But the trust was there before the teasing and the micro, and part of what made it a good experience was that they were extremely attentive to how much pushing they were doing.

This is exactly my aversion to it. I've been in several groups like this, and they all were extremely attentive to each other, but *were very explicit about status slopes*. It was important that I did NOT get to punch back, or criticize.

In moments where it was pretty much unthinkable to not let me punch, I could punch, but if I did their next punch back would literally floor me. I could criticize, but if I did I was guaranteed to have something horrifically disrespectful said about me in front of a girl or a boss or a parent. There were clear rules, and they included "you have to take it, and you aren't allowed to dish it back out", and those rules pretty much only applied to me.

I've also been in other groups where I WASN'T the butt-monkey, but there still was one - and I found that equally distasteful. So my natural spiritual reaction to 'bro' cliques is "look for the butt monkey", and I find the vigilance tiring.

Linda Linsefors I don't like the pendulum metaphor because it creates an intuition that social change will always (or usually) swing past the optimal trade off, to somewhere on the other side. I don't see why this intuition should be true in real life. Why should my prior be that it is more likely for any social change to go to far, rather than not far enough?
44

Like
 · Reply · 20w
Duncan Sabien Because that's happened literally every time?
22
Manage
Like
 · Reply · 20w
Linda Linsefors For any given social shift, it will probably have happened somewhere, at some time, that this change has been taken to far. But even a random walk would achieve that eventually. A pendulum implies that most times the norm shift from one stuck point to an other, it will pas the optimal trade-off. And I don't think that is true. I am pretty sure that the rights of [insert any historically discriminated group here] had to take many steps before it ever came anywhere close to the ideal.

Thinking about it though, maybe my confusion/disagreement is more with the stuck points than with the pendulum. If you identify stuck points with turning points, then you will by definition get a pendulum motion, swinging back and forth.

Like
 · Reply · 20w · Edited
Damon Max Pourtahmaseb-Sasi I think that the pendulum model is something that creates a lot of value as a reified thing, and helps us identify the failure mode of overcorrection and compensate for it when it occurs. I don't think we should take it for granted as what will happen "literally every time," or even (maybe?) the majority of the time.

It's very easy to identify hot-button issues in society where this happens, but I think the times it doesn't happen naturally fly under the radar because we just sort of stop thinking about them. On top of that, times where we have not yet swung past the "ideal point" should not be taken for granted that we will: only watched carefully to ensure we don't, or else there is a sort of golden mean fallacy that occurs where whatever one side is arguing fervently for comes off as an overcorrection, regardless of whether it is or not.

Examples of this that come to mind would be something like equal voter rights. What would swinging too far look like? Maybe giving 5 year olds the right to vote? People can argue about where the ideal point is, and some might want to expand voting rights to more people and some might want to restrict it to even less, but personally, I would push back against the idea that the pendulum ever swung too far for it. Curious if you'd disagree with that, Duncan?

Miranda Dixon-Luinenburg [Epistemic status: not 100% sure I understand what you’re gesturing at; I feel like I have a vague felt sense, but I might be talking about a different thing. Also, rambly and not sure if my point is coherent.]

I think I mostly agree with you, and my general attitude to life is that I’m responsible for owning my micro-experiences and I trust other people to be responsible for owning theirs.

However, I vaguely feel like there’s a thing around…maybe introspection and recognizing micro-state changes in myself, that the existence of this cultural shift towards naming/narrativizing/dignifying helped me get. It’s less that I didn’t think my micro-experiences were morally relevant for other people to care about, and more that I lacked the concept of that even being a *question*. This made it hard to notice certain types of experiences that were harmful to me…in particular, I think it might have been *impossible* for me to notice that I was asexual until I had some of the relevant narratives and concept-reification.

Like, the thing is I *took for granted* living in a world that was going to feel kind of coercive a lot of the time, and I was pretty good at rolling with it – and “sex I didn’t want” was maybe a 2 or 3 out of 10 on the negative experiences scale, which wasn’t high enough to register that much. In hindsight, I think I was taking a LOT of cumulative damage from this. (Though it’s hard to tell – did it become more traumatic in hindsight because of the narrative I put around it? Maybe the trauma didn’t *exist* until I had reified the concept of “feeling coerced to do sexual things is really bad.”)

And it turned out that having sex I didn’t want, unlike going to classes or work, *wasn’t mandatory*, and I could just…stop. I think it was, in the long run, a very large improvement to my wellbeing to be able to notice this, and set boundaries that are very different from most people’s and from societal standards. (And I don’t feel like it’s an especially large burden on people around me? I think this is an instance of me taking personal ownership of my micro-experiences, not expecting other people to feel responsible for them.)

This might be what you’re bringing up with “what this means is that, in my imagined culture, people on the more sensitive and susceptible end of things who are taking cumulative damage will have a harder time explaining and getting validation for what’s going wrong for them.” Though I take some exception to “sensitive and susceptible” – I think it’s sufficient for people to have unusual preferences along any dimension, and I feel like most people have unusual preferences along *some* dimension? And for all that the world is imperfect and there are a bunch of maybe-negative experiences you can’t avoid, it is possible to “adjust your seat” and ask for specific accommodations that would make it less shitty without imposing much cost on others – but only if you notice what to ask for.

Maybe there’s a way to give people the relevant introspection tools without the element of “and other people are responsible for predicting and mitigating your micro-harms”. I think you do gesture at that in the post, and it does feel like you’re advocating for “personal ownership of micro-experiences” rather than “no one cares about micro-experiences including their own” – but I don’t think I was *capable* of taking personal ownership until I had the narratives and vocabulary from this particular cultural paradigm.

Write a reply...
Nick Tarleton The part of this I find myself resisting most is:

> Part of the issue is that social ownership of the micro relies on something akin to equality-of-outcome rather than equality-of-treatment. Success in the social ownership paradigm is defined by whether or not other people actually avoid negative micro, and not by your own personal effort or integrity or adherence to social norms. That’s very, very different from a framework like NVC, which has similar motivations and intentions but describes a process to follow rather than a benchmark to achieve. In NVC, your locus of control as a person-who-wants-to-be-a-good-person is internal—are you doing the right things? Approaching conversations with the right mindset? When the micro is socially owned, the locus of control is external, and your sense of progress or self-worth is subject to chance and unfairness and human capriciousness and you can be drained dry via a sort of Hufflepuff trap that morally obligates you to continuously throw resources into a black hole.

because the intent paradigm feels [this also has the feeling that I might be missing something] like it makes feedback and accountability harder when someone doesn't have good intent; it's a lot easier to say 'stop taking that action' than 'have better intent'. It also leaves more room for unaccountability and gaslighting by someone who consciously does have good intent but is harming me anyway.

I want (as a fact about me, whether or not this would be part of a Correct set of norms) to be able to put social-ethical force behind a request I make for someone to stop doing something that hurts me.

Frameworks-for-being-a-good-person like NVC, if they're going to be the primary frameworks, seem to require a minimum level of sincerity and effort and self-examination from everyone that I really don't trust to always be present, or possible to create or select myself into.

I want to level the playing field, and that regrettably means removing the weapons you use to defend yourself, because my own have already been disarmed.

Write a reply...
Bridget Klish I think you make a lot of good points and I’d say I agree with somewhere around ~75% of them. My main quibble is with the characterization of reifying the micro as always (or almost always) leading to bad things. I’m going to try to summarize why as succinctly as possible but there’s a possibly I might get lost along the way to bear with me.

I am a white, straight, cis, educated, able-bodied woman from an upper-middle class background. Right away that infuses my position with a lot of privilege, and particularly in recent years, I’ve gone deeper into the rabbit hole (so to speak) of privilege vs. oppression, and as a result, a lot more things register as one or the other—I suppose I’ve become more “woke,” so to speak. I don’t claim to be entirely so, and I think in your ideal world that’s a good thing.

Now, my relative “woke”ness has had positives and negatives and I don’t think I can say which, if either, outweighs the other at this point, and I think it’s here that our feelings on your ideal will diverge a bit. I think your argument that “your model of me now has to include the fact that I’m modeling you, and my model of you has to take into account your modeling of me modeling you, and so forth” is edging somewhat into reductio-ad-absurdum territory, but I get what you’re saying and I agree at a basic level. This kind of thing has caused me stress in social situations because, having been accused of racism literally once in my life (to my face / that I know of), it’s an unpleasant experience to be told you’re acting in a way that makes another person feel that way, and also shocking in the sense that all of a sudden you’re realizing that someone sees you in a negative light that you never would have considered possible of yourself (note: I am in no way saying my negative reaction to being called racist is comparable to actually experiencing racism, but it was distressing nonetheless)—and thus I am trying very hard to not be racist (or ableist, or sexist, or whatever) and sometimes it’s difficult to be mindful of EVERY SINGLE PITFALL one could possibly take in those directions.

Is that making sense? Basically, while I would posit that everyone could do with being a little more “woke,” being such also means that you are aware of a lot more microaggressions and potential for being racist/sexist/whatever and this can create some mental stress. Which I believe you basically said, but a lot more eloquently.

It is also somewhat stressful to learn of/become more aware of ways in which I AM disadvantaged as a woman. I feel like I am much more on the lookout now for possible discrimination against me, especially now that I’m at the point where people will assume I’ll soon be having babies (married a few years, late 20s, etc.). So I’m constantly feeling on guard, like I have to prove myself, and on one hand show that I have no interest in babies (true) but on the other hand feeling like I shouldn’t HAVE to show that, because it’s wrong for women who want to have babies to be discriminated against.

BUT, being more aware of these things is also something of an advantage, particularly with #metoo and that sort of thing coming to light, because it’s easier to put my finger on why certain things make me uncomfortable, and it makes me feel more sane (?) and like I didn’t imagine something that made me feel weird or icky. I think it’s important that women are empowered to say “this makes me feel uncomfortable and that’s not okay,” and the first step to being able to say that is being able to let yourself FEEL that. And since women are socialized to be polite and quiet and accommodating, many of us have trained ourselves to ignore these sorts of feelings. So it’s been freeing to come to the realization that, hey, I DON’T actually have to put up with you being creepy because I’m expected to be polite.

Have I personally encountered a lot of that kind of thing? Luckily, no—but that’s not to say that I’ve NEVER experienced it. Have I had certain men say things to me in certain contexts that are perfectly fine, that in other contexts would send me running? Yep. Which brings me to another point: another challenge I’ve felt with being more “woke” is the instinct to let the pendulum swing ALL the way to one end, which left me wondering if I was a bad feminist for not being mad that the chef at my hotel calls me “baby.” The conclusion I’ve come to on that particular front is that I—and women/people in general—can sense when something is meant to be flirty vs. predatory vs. just someone’s personality (and in the particular case I mentioned, it’s just his personality, so it’s fine for me, but someone else might interpret it differently and that’s also okay and they have the right to ask him not to call them that).

All this to say that yes, I can see where you’re coming from and, again, I do agree on a basic level. But I do think that it’s important for people to realize that their actions, however small, could potentially have negative effects on people around them, however small those may be—because they CAN be cumulative and soul-crushing. It’s not really for you or me to say whether that’s the case for someone else.

I also take somewhat of an issue with your assertion that demonstrating more suffering becomes a positive in the sense that the squeakiest wheel gets the most grease…I guess mostly in the sense that it feels like you’re saying in terms of social justice that we’ve reached or passed the point where the pendulum swing stops being beneficial to the majority and starts being detrimental, and I don’t entirely agree with that. I think there are changes that still need to be made and issues that still need to be addressed. I think your concerns about *some* of the dimensions in which the pendulum has swung too far are certainly valid, though (the decrease in casual touch, especially between men, is definitely something that seems to have been detrimental to society as a whole) so don’t take this as a blanket “I don’t agree.” I just think it’s worth exploring some issues more deeply before claiming that recognizing and trying to combat microaggressions (for example) is a slippery slope to everyone playing the victim.

I don’t feel like this is very well organized or overly coherent, so I’m sorry if it doesn’t make any sense. So much for being succinct. But hopefully I’ve gotten at least something of a point across. Thanks for a good read :)

Damon Max Pourtahmaseb-Sasi Really enjoyed it. I think I'm still trying to find the words for what I think it overstates, but even with that, it still feels on a gut level to be in the ~85% range of correct, with most of that remaining portion being something about how the the failure modes may not be as pervasive or likely as they seems?

Like I have a very strongly liberal friendgroup, and never have I seen anyone within it engage in the nightmare scenario of people devoting debilitating amounts of energy into not offending each other, or in any death spirals of trying to compete over who sacrifices the most personal vitality/spontaneity to accommodate someone else. And it feels like I really should see that sort of thing happen more often than I do, with this model of the world.

(But maybe my social bubble naturally filters out the sorts of people who would do that, in the same vein that Scott Alexander mentions creationists, or how I know dozens of self-identified feminists but somehow don't know any of the kind that make feminism a bad word on the internet)

So now I'm wondering to what degree these failure modes might be over-represented within rationalist social circles, since it's the group that is most likely to reify such problems and paradoxically get caught up in the extreme forms of them? In a way that extends to maybe punch-buggy not being the optimal solution for society at large, but something a tad less intrusive toward personal boundaries but more encouraging toward letting people express displeasure without it being a call to act, or own the discomfort they cause others, in the sense of what risks/rewards that entails? Still thinking it over.

In any case, strong endorsement for coming out and saying this stuff, and props for putting it all together in such a cohesive way.

Jason Gross Thought I had, from reading your words: Trying to 80/20 socialized-masculinity and socialized-femininity:
- traditional-masculinity ≈ blurring/devaluing/calibrating the micro
- traditional-femininity ≈ reifying and reacting to the micro
Trying to 80/20 the toxic-vs-non-toxic part of masculinity and femininity, with regard to micro:
- toxic masculinity ≈ denying the existence of the micro, or suppressing it
- non-toxic masculinity ≈ well-calibrated / not-overly-sensitive micro
- non-toxic femininity ≈ being aware of and responsive to the micro
- toxic femininity ≈ taking responsibility for others' micro-experiences and making others responsible for one's own micro-experiences

This seems like a useful frame, and I'm curious if this description aligns with your views (Duncan) and whether it aligns with others'.

I think the world I want to see is one in where reifying and sharing microreactions is common and the default, and also the default is that one is responsible for one's own microexperiences. I think the thing I object to most in your imagined world is where you say "the culture rounds down to zero any hurt of magnitude three or less"; I want the world where hurts of magnitude three or less are welcomed in expression and validated by society and are not rounded down to zero, *and also* don't have to be fixed or changed.

Michael Porcelli A few addenda that have occurred to me, which I think triangulate with Duncan’s thesis.

Play fighting is normal in animal “cultural behavior” such as play fighting (cf wolf cubs). I think this calculates some social coordination strategies on behalf of the group that get cached in their brains for when physical violence is needed toward predators and prey. I think dominance and status play have a non-trivial biological causal factor to these behaviors in humans. But it would be commuting the naturalistic fallacy to assumes that this makes these behaviors “good” necessarily.

Societal simulations (cf Growing Artificial Societies) regularly show how social inequity arises consistently from randomized initial conditions with perfectly identical agents behaving according to completely fair rules. I think in evolutionary history (pre-human even) once our social brains started tracking these inequities for coalition building, we also began to develop heuristics for it (like dominance play). Once we get to human culture, a bunch of complicated ways to signal, counter signal, and deceive got layered on top of this. Again, this isn’t a normative justification for inequity, but I think it is a causal explanation.

Cognitive Behavioral Therapy (CBT) has two techniques that I think align with these Duncan’s thesis. The first is “exposure therapy” which is a deliberate practice of repeated experiences of a disturbing stimulus in order to decrease further disturbance in the future. The second is recognizing exaggerated, overgeneralized, self-defeating interpretations of one's circumstances and disturbing events, and recalibrating then to reflect reality more accurately. I believe both of these practices are beneficial. The norms of social justice when it comes to micro-aggressions run directly in opposition to these practices.

Meditation also provides two insights in this conversation. The first one is the effectiveness of tilting people towards emotional equanimity. Though emotions still arise, they don’t “hook” one as easily or strongly as before. Think of it as sensitivity without reactivity, or as equanimity without numbness. The second one is how meditation practice tilts one towards increasing “dis-identification”. This is easily misunderstood to means rejection of roles, preferences, group, or history. Instead, it simply turns down the stickiness of those things, liberating one from simply acting out the given roles one identifies as.

I think the ancient ideas in stoicism align with the benefits of both meditation and CBT.

All this considered, in addition to Duncan’s arguments, I still don’t think the result is a crystal clear and unmoving ethical boundary.

On the one hand, I think that the norms can move historically in the direction of “tightening up” once grosser level injustices have been mostly resolved (like how we focus on unconscious bias and systemic oppression now as opposed to just outright bigotry like lynchings and Jim Crow).

On the other hand, I think a cost-benefit trade-off curve hits the diminishing returns inflection point, which is something like what I think Duncan is gesturing toward. I think there’s some naturally occurring social limiter that kicks in, often under the label “backlash”.

I think at any given historical moment, we could find a sweet spot which incrementally improves upon historical gains but gives way around the inflection point. However, I also think for Reasons the fitness landscape itself changes through time, which means that sweet spot moves, albeit I think at a slower time scale.

I remember conversations like this back in my years at university in the ‘90’s, where PC was much more popular than it was in the ‘00’s. Now it’s back, and I think it’s moving towards a new balance point.

Lorelei Richards Rough attempt to make cruxes for my position, after Duncan Sabien 's earlier comment.
- being shown that reifying the micro makes already high trust environments lower trust, as people follow a supposed incentive gradient to trade their current interactions for the more basal validation of safety, rather than something that makes currently low trust individuals more willing to participate in higher trust interactions than before acknowledging micro things.
- being shown that norms of higher trust and letting the micro be a wash actually result in currently low trust people just learning to participate and get value from this culture, instead of scaring them away or resulting in abuse.

These are the like... Observable things that would make me update, I think.

Ethan Ashkie Duncan I’ve been thinking about your piece / my headcanon more over the last few days. You’ve made a real brainburner!!

Two more pseudo/super-philosophical questions:

Write a reply...
Tobias Everett Gurl [Note: I'm not part of the rationalist community, but I'm going to do my best to mimic your speech conventions so that we have terminology in common. This is directly contrary to my normal mode of speech which goes out of its way to avoid jargon in order to bypass the accumulated emotional reactions of its listeners/readers to that jargon. If something I'm saying sticks out as the opposite of what it looks like the rest of my post means, it would be more efficient to then ask me if it's what I really meant rather than assuming, since it could very well be due to an unintentional terminology problem, and assuming I meant the weird thing could get us lost in argument weeds where we're not even really disagreeing. Foreign language speakers make mistakes, etc.]

Meta-level agreement: near-complete. I noticed this phenomenon in the Bay Area with my then-wife, who had suffered from severe depression for as long as she could remember. Before we moved to Oakland she received what I'd consider an American-standard level of validation and accommodation. She wasn't spat on or regularly told that it was all in her head, but she was also expected to complete her school work, and when she didn't meet even the extensions she was granted, her grades suffered as a result. She was given more latitude than students without depression, but there were still consequences to her failures, and she didn't expect everyone to contort themselves around her whims. We (myself being the most notable example) often still did, but that was on our own initiative because she was someone we cared about.

That changed in the Bay where she had an internship with a disability rights group. Because they were a disability rights group, and because of the nature of the internship program we were in, going to work was now optional for her. Her job site enabled every excuse she had for staying home. It - and the surrounding culture - validated her pain to the point where she no longer faced any consequences for giving in to it, and her expectations of others shifted in response. Now, anyone who demanded anything of her at all was imposing on her boundaries, whether they could have anticipated that or not. I watched her reify her experiences being asked to do things as oppression against the neurodivergent; expand her definition of who was out to get her; and become less happy as a result of her increased sensitivity. (This is on top of the natural unhappiness that occurs when you reconceptualize treating your own depression as giving in to The Man, and consequently leave it untreated.)

I do disagree with you on how you prioritize and describe the ways the social ownership of the micro 'goes wonky' in social justice spaces, but it's more an addition/clarification than any deep divergence. You say:

"We’ve already seen glimmers of this kind of dynamic in the social justice sphere, where there is sometimes an implicit moral hierarchy with the most aggrieved and downtrodden at the top, and the most privileged at the bottom. The more legitimate one’s claim to suffering or damage, the more seriously one’s requests/demands that others change their behavior in response are taken."

In my experience, there are two axes that can go into claiming suffering and consequently demanding accommodation: first, level of oppression; and second, outspokenness. The second is an invisible condition that gets overlooked when analyzing the, I dunno, justice in social justice. It's assumed that if there is injustice in how accommodations play out, it will be along the lines of excessively punishing those who are most privileged, when that's not how it typically goes at all. Similar to how (almost?) everyone involved in America's social justice movements can read, and thus aren't the most disadvantaged people in the world, you need a certain level of aggression and confidence in order to force social justice communities to bend to your will. Sometimes that's a good thing, especially when you're sticking up for a marginalized group that isn't in vogue, but it also creates a toxic dynamic where the people who are most often demanding accommodation are just self-interested bullies who don't even care about what they're arguing. They tend to be mid-level on whatever the oppression hierarchy is in their space (trans, female, and a lesbian, but also white, neurotypical, etc.), which gives them enough clout to argue the supremacy of their own oppression while not being beaten down by, you know, having literally everything in the world laid against them. This is a VERY IMPORTANT DISTINCTION, both for insiders looking to create functional communities, and for outsiders looking to critique the failures of dysfunctional ones.

Object-level agreement as related to punch-buggy: very little agreement, but also a recognition of personal bias. I grew up playing slug bug (as we called it) with my dad. I had fun with it at first, but around when I turned 16 or 17 I stopped enjoying it because of how it felt competitive, and by that time in my life I'd started dreading competition. I don't know how I internalized it, but over time I developed two feelings that I'm still struggling to get rid of: 1) I hated losing, because losing meant I was a loser, and everything was awful forever; and 2) I hated winning, because when I won that meant the other person/people was/were subjected to the same negative feelings I would have been feeling if I'd lost.

Based on how you're describing recalibration around a benign imposition, where slug bug represents a harmless loss of control, that should also have applied to me and my fear of competition. Absolutely nothing was at stake in our slug bug matches except pride. By your model it should have helped prepare me for inconsequential failure instead of feeling like an overwhelming failure on its own - but it clearly didn't.

(Come to think of it, the fact that only pride was on the line might have been part of the problem. Pride is harder to quantify, and it might harm someone's ability to trust that the person they're playing with truly doesn't think you're lesser if there isn't a ritualistic element of reassurance, like the loser buying the winner a small ice cream cone or something. I see a similar problem in my roleplaying games, where enormous grudges can break out after an in character event where winners and losers are decided based on rolling dice, and nobody loses anything except face. Without rituals of reaffirmation afterward, players sometimes walk away unsure of whether the conflict was only in character, and worry that the other player thinks they're beneath them because they lost.)

Anyway, as written, your slug bug model doesn't account for my experience, either because it wouldn't apply to the fear of competition problem (which from my perspective looks similar to the social control of the micro in the anxieties it produces); or because there's something missing from your implementation; or because it's a flawed idea in the first place.

I really enjoyed the piece overall, and I think I learned from it. I'm also interested in discussing my own conclusions with you in the interest of further refinement of what I think is a good idea.

Jason Gross I like this subthread, and it brought slight tears to my eyes. There's a skill I'm wanting to offer you Duncan, or see you use more, which I generally see you as being rather skilled with (and I think I'm noticing a lack of it in these threads), which is something like noticing when you are failing to assume positive regard, and bringing it a way that brings the sides closer together. I think this is what I was pointing at with my comment late in Paul's thread.

Rambling about my experience which I hope might be valuable: When I fail to assume positive regard, it usually says something interesting about me, and something interesting about what is going on in the interaction that I'm having. It rarely directly says something interesting about the other person, in my experience. I also find that I can generally find positive regard if I go up a level or two or three of meta. If it's not the case that they feel positively towards me right now, perhaps they want to feel positively towards me. If that's not the case, perhaps they want the world to be such that they can feel positively towards more people. If not, perhaps they are trying to meet some unmet need, and if that need were met, they would satisfy one of the lower levels meta. If someone isn't respecting me, perhaps they respect the norms that allow peaceful conversation. If not, perhaps they want to respect those norms, but are having trouble for a good reason. If not, perhaps they have an unmet need, and if that need were met, they'd respect the conversational norms, or me.
There's a skill I've been training which seems related, which is noticing when I'm attached to something, and tracing the source of attachment, and another skill which I am much less leveled in of learning to seek what I want without attachment.

Write a reply...
Tyrrell McAllister That was a fascinating article. It cuts across issues in a way that I didn't expect.

I went in to the article with something very close to your view on social justice rhetoric. I wasn't surprised to find myself in 100% agreement with your Part 5. From my perspective, your Part 5 is pitch-perfect on all levels: in your tone, in the position that you stake out, in your arguments, and in your sympathetic-but-alarmed characterization of the opposing position. All of it is something that I would have been proud to have written.

And yet, I am really viscerally uncomfortable with slug bug.

It's clear to me that this discomfort has to do with the bullying that I experienced in childhood. Specifically, it's part of my self-narrative that the bullying stopped when I figured out how to exude a credible aura that said "I expect my physical autonomy to be respected".

So, when I imagine being with someone who is contemplating punching me in a game of slug bug, there's definitely a part of my mind that thinks, "That needs to be put down right now. It's not physically dangerous yet, but physical danger and humiliation is on the horizon if you don't put an immediate stop to it."

By extension, that part of my mind reads your Part 6 and thinks, "Danger! Someone is trying to discourage you from discouraging people from punching you!"

In the scheme of things, the bullying that I suffered was pretty minor. And it's far in the past. On the whole, I don't *really* feel threatened. But I can still imagine a younger me reading Part 6 in isolation and thinking, "Well, I've got to put a stop to that." It's a vestigial part of my mind, but I can still evoke it with a little imaginative priming.

This gives me a bit more of an inkling of how strong an imperative to "own the micro" is felt by people who've suffered much greater trauma.

The upshot is that, by framing your/my position against "social ownership of the micro" in terms of slug bug, you've made me realize in a new way at a visceral level how compelling the opposing position is.

Like
 · Reply · 19w
Glenn Willen I have not read the post yet, but this comment resonated with me as someone whose natural position _seems_ to be against the thrust of the essay (but having not read it, all I can really say is that it's anti-punch-bug.)

After trying to compose a comment about this several times, what I ended up with is this: My experience of 'punch bug' and the like, typically during childhood but occasionally similar things in adulthood, was not as physical abuse but rather as a play for dominance. The punch is not the part that causes fear -- I know it will never be hard (at least among adults / people with some sense.) The fear comes from the knowledge that I am always and perpetually subject to rules I have no good opportunity to learn or challenge, and anyone can at any time make a dominance play against me by applying such rules, and I will always lose (because I'm not part of the set that makes / understands / deals in them, and I have no real way to know the difference between a "real" game and one that was just made up on the spot for cruelty's sake.)

This fear does _not_ apply to punch bug itself at the object level, because I am now familiar with it (as long as a request to _not_ play is considered okay.) It applies at the meta level to all the games of this form I _haven't_ heard of until they are played upon me.

Since I haven't read the essay yet -- it does look quite long, and reading it is probably going to be kind of stressful, see above -- I'm not totally sure whether my feelings expressed here are with/against/orthogonal/related to it.

Anisha Mauze I feel like The Game is another interesting example of this, which is just different enough from Punch Buggy to note a few interesting things. When someone says "[You/I] just lost The Game", you do sometimes get reactions similar to in Punch Buggy (ranging from "dammit" to "that's immature/I don't play" to outrage). Of course, the "outrage" section is smaller (1 or 2 in 10 rather than 3 in 10, to estimate). It's interesting to note who reacts badly to Punch Buggy but not The Game because there, it's clearly about violence. In those who react badly to both, it seems to be more about losing.

I get that this is sticky. You want to get consent from the person before punching them, but saying "do you play punch buggy" because you see a Bug is basically asking "can I punch you" and feels uncomfortable, and there's also something socially strange to asking that outside the context of seeing one (unless it's on a road trip or something?). I remember playing this with my little brother as a kid. I was annoyed the first time he punched me, but then eventually I got him back and it became fun. Of course, part of this is because I didn't have much of a choice but to play. If I had said "dude, I don't want to play this game", he would have continued to do it *anyway*, and *that* is where I have a problem. This is the kind of thing where if someone says they don't want to play, you had better respect that.

My feelings are complicated around the parts that more clearly correlate to sexual consent. I remember having friends as a kid who would complain if I punched them in the name of "punch buggy", but would punch me back if they saw one first, and that is just not okay. And sometimes, it's hard to differentiate that from "I'm in a bad moon, please don't punch me today".

Glenn Willen ... this is interesting to me because I just said in my comment above that -- for me -- it wasn't really about violence, but in fact I don't really care about The Game in the way that I do about Punch Buggy. So although I said above that it's about dominance and not violence, really it seems to be about dominance-through-violence, where token violence still counts, but a mere declaration of losing does not. Even a slight, token amount of violence still counts as making a claim that you can freely do violence against me, but the abstract declaration that I have lost a game doesn't really _interact_ with me unless I'm choosing to play the game. (That is, as an adult with reasonable emotional control.)

Oliver Riley Stanley There’s a concept I’m struggling to express in response to the notion that explicitly asking about playing punch buggy feels uncomfortable.

On the level of the specific case, you can have the conversation in a different context, or failing that make a guess about whether the other person will be game based on your knowledge of (and relationship with) them.

If having *any* kind of explicit discussion is off the table, but you still don’t want to face the potential consequences of guessing wrong (your friend being angry with you and/or punching you even though you declared ‘no-punch-backs’), then you’re stuck getting more information some other presumably-implicit guess-culturey way.

If person A wants to initiate Thing with person B without actually checking if B is into Thing, A is taking responsibility for the chance B is not, in fact, into Thing. The consequences for A of being wrong vary widely depending on Thing. In some cases the combination of high confidence and small consequence are sufficient for A to be comfortable taking that gamble, and A can perhaps take less-than-explicit information-gathering actions to calibrate their confidence as a safeguard. But it hardly seems legitimate for A to then complain in those cases where guessing doesn’t work. That’s the price of guessing. Either do more homework next time, or actually use your words.

Lorelei Richards Duncan Sabien, I think you're capturing a lot of important and accurate information about the shape of the world wrt to this domain of social interactions, but missing some important pieces of the "micro" crowd's motivations, and I get the impression you want to pull the pendulum directly back a bit, when there's in fact a more orthogonal direction to move norms in that maintain important pieces of what the people who are worried about micro care about, without damaging the things you care about as much.

I have some fairly well developed intuitions about this, but have trouble articulating what i think norms *should* look like wrt issues like this.

Lorelei Richards there's a certain sense of... safety, i think is about the right word, that people really really benefit a lot from, and is I think actually perhaps one of the most limiting factors in the output of the rationalist community is a lack of trust in this safety. from https://www.lesswrong.com/.../thoughts-on-the-reach...

"And I got a strong sense that there’s a surplus of pent-up organizational energy in Berkeley – lots of people who would totally step up to run events if they were given the affordance to."

I think micro is actually a huge deal, and that it's micro because people aren't noticing how much actual damage little things can add up to, if you don't have the trust that people are behaving in good faith. I pay a lot of attention to small things in other people, try and actively generate precise theory of mind, predict and remove small stressors when communicating with someone or trying to talk about how they could best improve. humans are *incredible* and brilliant and capable, rationalists especially, and you merely need to find a way to let people feel like they're allowed to do things, that it's safe to try, and then they *do*.

there's... everything is messy here, i dont have high confidence on exactly the structure of what's going on, it's possible there are people afraid of being hurt, and other people afraid of being punished for doing small harms if they try anything clever or hard or ambitious, and these camps dont realize they're paralyzing the other.

Brent Dill Duncan Sabien I'm speaking not just for myself, here, but for many people that I've had intimate experience with:

Most people who need higher safety, only need it for awhile. "Incentivizing being needy or hurt" is a solvable problem, because if you pay attention you can *ACTUALLY TELL* who has actual extraordinary needs vs. who's just following the incentives to be needy or hurt or whatever. Of course, almost no one actually pays attention, but that's a problem at the *OTHER END* of this situation.

I think one of the things that people are hoping you'll signal here, that I haven't really seen addressed, is that you're *actually paying attention* to who legitimately has (temporary or permanent) higher needs for safety, vs. who is just attempting to create an incentivization schema wherein they get to demand anything in the interest of their "safety".

Brent Dill John Salvatier Well, only if you need extra safety that's *outside the norm*. Like, I need LESS safety than most people, it's just that most of the safety that most people need is suffused into subconscious social assumptions that don't matter to me, whereas most of the safety that *I* need is outside of those bounds. So in a room with 99 other people, 99 of them are each surprised by me, whereas I'm only surprised by the collective group of them once.

Daniel Powell One of my intuitions that I had to override on the entire "pendulum" metaphor was that there were some axes where the ideal wasn't in the center, but desirability increased monotonically.

"Some cultures are more Just than others; the 'Justnes' pendulum, in practice, semi-randomly walks just like all the others- but surely more justice is /strictly/ better, all other things being equal?"

The synopsis of how I broke out of that is that motion along each of the metaphorical axes is not independent- there is no way for "all other things to be equal". It's not even not zero sum, and we probably aren't on the Pareto Frontier of possible norms.

Daniel Powell On the negative-one meta: It is /unsafe/ to punch me by surprise, even if you are a friend of mine and even if I would retrospectively acknowledge e.g. that eye gouging is a horrifyingly disproportionate response. I'm almost certainly not going to a catastrophic failure by surprise, but I can't be transparent about when I might.

That isn't an argument for banning Punch Bug, although it is information that might cause people not to play it.

Pulling that to the subject: Properly Caring about small (~4 times/lifetime) chances of catastrophic harm is harder than properly caring about harms with the magnitude and frequency of the ones described, but almost certainly are more costly to get wrong.

I expect that more people in this filter bubble make the error of overcorrecting, and are being too careful with people because they consider the (cost of breaking someone * the marginal expected number of people that end up broken) to be much higher than e.g. (cost of making someone feel coerced into a conversation * chance that they will). While I doubt that anyone will endorse that as relating to their True Objection, I think that it is really informative that [I had a real concrete example, but predicted that the concrete example would become the subject and also it would be insensitive to name groups] - when trying to establish how bad a situation or condition is, people tend to be less sensitive to descriptions of the typical person in that position than they are to absolutely small differences in suicide rate among people in that position.

Anyone on the side of playing Punch Bug without n^2 bilateral agreements already accepts some of the rather small risk that one of those strangers is going to misparse the battery as an existential threat. I think that for the specific case of Punch Bug, that's a reasonable thing to decide after doing the math. But for some of the things that Punch Bug is a metaphor of, I think people would shift their beliefs if they took some actual time to look at the likelihood and magnitude of the unlikely outcomes, without trying to virtue signal by altering severity.

Raymond Arnold Observation about the memetic construction of the essay:

"Punch Buggy" is serving here as a symbol that gives the essay rhetorical, well, punch. It's the main source of the essay's potential _virulence_ (i.e. being memetically powerful enough to get shared, talked about, engaged with). If Duncan had chosen a less controversial symbol, fewer people would have bothered to read a 14,000 word essay.

The tradeoff this makes is that the symbol ends up getting engaged with more than the idea. I notice that as the discussion continues, I have a _harder and harder_ time remembering that the point is "social management of the micro" as opposed to "Punch Buggy in particular." I also find myself more and more orienting around the frame of the viscerally anti-punch-buggy crowd, since that's the facet of the conversation with the most emotional pull.

A bunch of people are saying reasonable things, and I read them and said "ah, that's quite reasonable", and then a paragraph below is people arguing about victimhood and bullying and my brain goes "ah! now _that_'s juicy!" and the dominant thing I remember when I walk away is "victim and bullyhood sure are salient".

I had to work to remember that the important question was "how do I re-examine interactions through the frame of 'social management of the micro' even when those interactions don't involve anything like violence?"

I'm not making a claim here about whether Duncan made the right set of tradeoffs in the essay – packaging a complex idea that you think society needs to take seriously (even a small filter bubble) is obnoxiously hard and I don't any alternate ideas on how to have done this one.

Thomas Eliot I like the idea, wrote my main response to the essay elsewhere, and so will just reiterate my tl;dr here: the main virtue we should be teaching people that I think this essay is pointing at is "know how to take a punch, metaphorically and literally" to which I think it is crucial to add "and know how to throw a punch". You can't win fights just by taking punches well. If you don't believe me, I can show you the scar.

In particular, I do not understand how the game of punch bug teaches these skills. It seems to me that the game, particularly the "no hitting back" rule, teaches people to be passive victims, which is the opposite of what I want.

If someone hits me, I will hit them back.

Damon Max Pourtahmaseb-Sasi I think the idea is supposed to be that if you get punched in Punch Buggy, you accept that it's not a big deal and you just let it slide, because you KNOW that at some later time you will see a buggy and get YOUR punch in.

The analogy is that sometimes someone will do something that hurts your feelings, but you let it slide because sometimes you will do something that hurts their feelings. If you just hit someone back every time they hit you, no matter how lightly, well, that's how passive aggressive feuds start bigger fights.

Punch Buggy works as the analogy because it's mostly totally unpredictable, like the things we will do that hurt others. Punch Buggy does not work as the analogy because it still requires a conscious decision to punch someone after seeing a buggy :P

But one thing that Duncan is worried about is that people who try too hard not to punch someone after seeing a buggy are losing spontaneity and fun and individual expression... just because that results in a slight, temporary pain to someone else.
